bug_description:
Bug Title: Unexpected NaN Value in "Rotation" Method Due to Faulty Conditional Statement

Step-by-step Bug Description:

1. The bug resides in the "Rotation" method of a vector mathematical operation module.

2. The "Rotation" method uses vector-based computation to perform rotation operations based on four input vectors (u1, u2, v1, v2).

3. Initially, the method calculates the squared norms of all the inputs.

4. If any of these squared norms equals zero, it throws an IllegalArgumentException, stating that the rotation defining vector has a zero norm. This works as expected.

5. The next part of the method normalizes v1 and adjusts v2 based on the dot product and some constants.

6. Then, the method assigns some values to various variables for further calculation, including a cross product operation and dot product operation.

7. The bug locates in the following if condition block:
   ```
   if (c == 0) { .... }
   ```
   In this block, it performs various mathematical operations for different conditions. The "c" variable is calculated from a dot product of two vectors. The problem arises when "c" is exactly zero, it does not consider the case where "c" might be very small but not exactly zero.

8. The test case fails as it expects the "beta" value to be valid numeric value, but due to the misunderstanding on zero check, it ends up with NaN which henceforth fails the following computations and throws a junit.framework.AssertionFailedError.

9. The condition "if (c == 0)" is repeated three times in different places in the code, which all share the same bug.

Recommended Fix:

The issue can be solved by replacing the exact zero condition checking with a threshold check. A small constant value (like inPlaneThreshold in the provided fixed code) is used and if "c" is smaller than this threshold value, it is considered to be near-zero and hence the condition will be true. This prevents the situation where "c" takes an almost zero value and the computation ends up with the NaN. If c is less than or equal to zero, it should also be treated as the same case. This fix is applied in all three places where "c" is checked against zero.
